MSJS Banning: College to stay open during review process/PE

May 20th, 2012

http://www.pe.com/local-news/riverside-county/the-pass/the-pass-headlinesindex/20120518-banning-college-allowed-to-stay-open-during-review.ece

FYI

“MSJC’s Pass campus in Banning will be able to continue operating while the college prepares a court-ordered environmental report about site development activity.  The judge gave the college up to six months to circulate a draft environmental report on the work already done at the site and work anticipated in the San Gorgonio Pass Campus 2050 Facilities Master Plan reviewed by college trustees in July 2010.

“The district owned site is on the southeast corner of Sunset and Westward avenues, south of Interstate 10.”

Blog:

Education Code 81033 clearly states the a “governing board of a district prior to acquiring any site on which it proposes to construct any school building shall have the site investigated by competent personnel to ensure that the final site selection is determined by an evaluation of all factors affecting the public interest and is not limited to selection on the basis of raw land  cost only.”

This land was cheap.  The location has huge drainage/flood issues and there are three (3) high pressure gas lines nearby, one of which is 1500 ft from the center.  The required EIR will address these issues.

Community college leaders lobby for tax hike/NCTimes

May 17th, 2012

FYI

http://www.nctimes.com/news/local/sdcounty/education-community-college-leaders-lobby-for-tax-hike/article_d9d066a8-968f-5cee-8c06-0ef022f31c02.html?oCampaign=email

“It would be more helpful if they educated the voters about the high salaries some of these administrators are making.  These folks have no conscience.  The money being devoured by the school bureaucracies is one of the principal factors driving the cost of education.”  Kris Vosburgh, Howard Jarvis Taxayers Assoc.

Blog:

The last place these folks will make cuts is to themselves.  Our state has a spending problem, not a revenue problem.  Recent budget cuts affect class sections and access for our students.  There are no student waiting lists anymore. Our colleges have become more institutionally centered than student centered.

College faculty, staff, protest raises to two administrators/San Marcos

May 17th, 2012

FYI

http://www.nctimes.com/news/local/san-marcos/san-marcos-college-faculty-staff-protest-raises-to-two-administrators/article_df3a2121-79f1-5ff5-885b-f11ba86008c5.html?oCampaign=email

“Palomar College staff and faculty members last week protested the board’s decision to raise pay for two administrators by 10 and 19 percent, while most Palomar staff have gone four years without a raise.”

“Forty-seven administrators, including President Deegan,  and other vice presidents, the college’s deans and various superviors directors and managers, earned a total of about %5.6 million in 2010.”

Blog:

Boards act upon the recommendation of the Superintendent President and few elected trustees say “NO”. Community colleges across the state are reducing class sections (”workload reductions”) so why do these fat cats think they need a raise?

This is exactly why taxpayers don’t want to provide the state more dollars.

“The coming meltdown in college education”/Blog Maverick

May 14th, 2012

FYI

http://blogmaverick.com/2012/05/13/the-coming-meltdown-in-college-education-why-the-economy-wont-get-better-any-time-soon/
“Remember the housing meltdown?  A lot of easy money being lent to buyers who couldn’t afford the money they were borrowing.  That money was then spent on homes with the expectation that the price of the home would go up and it could be easily flipped or refinanced at a profit.  When easy money stopped, buyers couldn’t sell.  They couldn’t refinance.  Housing prices crashed.”

“It’s far too easy to borrow money for college. Right now there is a never ending supply of buyers. Students borrow as much money as you can for the best school you can get into and afford and then believe you “flip” that education for the great job you are going to get when you graduate.”

“Except those great jobs aren’t always there. Today, the minute you graduate college you face the challenge of debt against a college education whose value is immediately, “underwater”.”

Blog:

It’s time to rethink how education is delivered in California.  Time for all three of our state institutions (UC/CSU/CCC) to come together and provide online bachelors degree with open enrollments at minimum cost to the user. The potential to provide educational opportunity to thousands more students depends upon it.

MIT and Harvard announce edX/Chronicle

May 2nd, 2012

“Joint partnership builds on MITx and Harvard distance learning: aims to benefit campus-based education and beyond.”

“Harvard University and MIT today announced “edX” a transformational new partnership in online education. Through edX, the two institutions will collaborate to enhance campus-based teaching and learning and build a global community of online learners.”

http://chronicle.com/blogs/wiredcampus/harvard-and-mit-put-60-million-into-new-platform-for-free-online-courses/36284?sid=pm&utm_source=pm&utm_medium=en

http://web.mit.edu/press/2012/mit-harvard-edx-announcement.html

Blog:

The key word and purpose is “global”.  The future of education is for an educated workforce in a “global” employment market.  Presently, the US is at the lower/bottom ranks (25th) in world educational achievement, and thus, the concept of global online learning opportunities from noted academic institutions is attractive.

California education has become institutionally centered in preservation of it’s human resources rather than in provision of educational opportunity to the public it was purposed to serve.  Reduction in budgets will require a new way to think.  Those at MIT/Harvard are doing so.  So should California.
